awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing a framework to identify and mitigate perceptual and technical barriers in code sharing to facilitate reproducible and transparent research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will conduct exploratory research into the barriers and strategies for making research code publicly accessible.  While there has been significant progress in making research datasets accessible for purposes of open science and reproducibility, code and other forms of software developed in research projects are less frequently made available persistently.  In scientific research, it is not only imperative to publish a detailed description of the study design, methodology, results, and interpretation, but there is a pressing need to make all the research products (including code and software) publicly available, shareable, well documented, and organized to facilitate reproducible and transparent research.

An important research product that is an essential element ensuring reproducible research is the analytic code used for the analysis. In contrast to sharing data, which is widely enforced by scientific journals and research organizations, there is limited guidance on code sharing which in addition to data represents an essential component of reproducible and rigorous research.  The project will result in: A) Descriptive information which will be collected through one-to-one interviews through teleconferencing, as well as by distributing surveys across 5,000 randomly selected principal investigators who were supported by NSF and/or NIH, B) Recommendations for code sharing to be developed through a series of structured teleconferences with informed experts, notably editors of scientific journals with a strong interest in code sharing and reproducible research, and C) Formation of a Research Code Alliance (RCA) to develop a framework to mitigate perceptual and technical barriers in code sharing to facilitate reproducible and transparent research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to enhance our understanding of the barriers researchers face in effectively organizing and sharing analytical code, with the ultimate goal of identifying strategies to overcome both perceptual and technical barriers in code sharing to promote reproducible and transparent research practices. Modern data-driven research across various disciplines has become increasingly dependent on quantitative analysis. However, mechanisms ensuring analysis transparency, effective code and software sharing, rigor, and reproducibility are currently lacking. In contrast to data sharing, which is widely enforced by scientific journals and research organizations, there is limited guidance on code sharing, which, in addition to data, represents an essential component of reproducible and rigorous research. Current efforts mostly rely on individual researchers, although many journals and agencies have taken the initiative to ensure code availability; however, the effectiveness of such initiatives remains unknown. When code is shared alongside the results of the analysis, other researchers can curate, examine, and reuse the code in ways that enhance its value and lead to novel discoveries and insights. To identify the perceptual and technical barriers that researchers encounter when striving to ensure code availability, usability, readability, organization, and reproducibility, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of more than 450 studies, evaluating their code-sharing practices. Our study generated valuable insights into the challenges researchers face when sharing code, encompassing both perceptual and technical obstacles. We gathered descriptive data to pinpoint these challenges, including issues related to code accessibility, usability, readability, organization, and reproducibility. Additionally, we developed a comprehensive set of recommendations aimed at addressing both perceptual and technical barriers in code sharing, ultimately promoting reproducible and transparent research. The recommendations provided by our study will assist the scientific community in adopting best practices for sharing and organizing code, ensuring rigor and reproducibility in their research, and fostering scientific progress across a variety of disciplines.
